Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, \u00a.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, Jessica Thompson, pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, § 28 and other applicable statutes, and respectfully petitions this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody and parenting time order entered by this Court on May 15, 2022.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: The Bristol County Probate and Family Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, as this Court entered the original Judgment of Custody on May 15, 2022, and jurisdiction over the parties and the minor children continues under applicable law.

G.L. c. 209B, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is appropriate under G.L. c. 209B, § 2, as both parents and the children reside within Bristol County, Massachusetts.

Dupre v. Dupre, 464 Mass. 198 (2013).proposition: Since the issuance of the original order, a substantial and material change in circumstances has arisen that warrants a modification of the custody arrangement to serve the best interests of the minor children, pursuant to Dupre v. Dupre, 464 Mass. 198 (2013), and Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996).
Dupre v. Dupre, 464 Mass. 198 (2013).case_name: HSBC Bank USA, N.A. v. Matt
Dupre v. Dupre, 464 Mass. 198 (2013).support_reasoning: This opinion concerns standing to bring a servicemember (SCRA) proceeding in the Land Court in a mortgage foreclosure context, not modification of child custody orders. It does not address family law, material changes in circumstances, or the best interests of minor children, and therefore cannot support the stated custody‑modification proposition. The citation to Dupre v. Dupre, 464 Mass. 198 (2013), appears to be erroneous in this context.
Dupre v. Dupre, 464 Mass. 198 (2013).relevant_excerpt: “We turn next to whether a plaintiff must be a mortgagee to establish standing in a servicemember proceeding, or whether, as the judge determined, standing may be established upon a showing that a plaintiff holds a right to purchase a mortgage.”

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: Since the issuance of the original order, a substantial and material change in circumstances has arisen that warrants a modification of the custody arrangement to serve the best interests of the minor children, pursuant to Dupre v. Dupre, 464 Mass. 198 (2013), and Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996).
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely applies G.L. c. 208, § 28’s “material and substantial change in circumstances” standard in the context of a complaint for modification of custody and affirms that modification is appropriate when such a change has occurred and a new order is necessary in the children’s best interests. While the case ultimately reverses the particular split-custody arrangement, it expressly upholds the judge’s finding that the mother’s rehabilitation constituted a material and substantial change justifying consideration of a modified custody order. Thus it supports citing Ardizoni for the general proposition about the need to show a substantial and material change to warrant modification in the children’s best interests.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt:
“General Laws c. 208, § 28…enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’…

In allowing the wife’s complaint for modification, the judge cited as a material and substantial change in circumstances, the wife’s ‘great success in overcoming her alcohol and drug dependence.’…Hence, the finding that a material and substantial change in circumstances had occurred was not clearly erroneous.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Over the past year, Defendant has repeatedly enrolled the minor children in extracurricular activities that conflict with Plaintiff’s regular parenting time, without consulting Plaintiff or obtaining her agreement, in violation of the spirit of joint legal custody as defined in Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: Rolde does not involve joint legal custody at all; the court affirms an award of sole custody to the mother and explicitly rejects joint custody as inappropriate in that case. While the opinion contains general dicta that joint custody is ‘synonymous with joint decision making’ and requires mutual cooperation on major child‑rearing decisions, it does not define any enforceable ‘spirit of joint legal custody’ or address issues like one parent unilaterally enrolling children in activities during the other’s parenting time. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “Joint custody is synonymous with joint decision making and a common desire to promote the children’s best interests. … ‘[J]oint custody requires two capable parents with some degree of respect for one another’s abilities as parents, together with a willingness and ability to work together to reach results on major decisions in a manner similar to the way married couples make decisions.’ … The judge concluded that ‘joint custody or shared responsibility is an invitation to continued warfare and conflict.’”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: This behavior undermines Plaintiff’s relationship with the children and constitutes a violation of the existing order prohibiting disparagement, as addressed in Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion in Custody of Kali does not discuss parental disparagement, non-disparagement orders, or conduct that undermines a parent–child relationship in the sense described in the proposition. The case focuses on standards for initial custody determinations (best interests, primary caregiver, stability) under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), and the effect of temporary custody orders. It therefore provides no authority for the claim that certain behavior violates an order prohibiting disparagement or undermines the other parent’s relationship with the children.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge… However, we will not sustain an award of custody ‘unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.’ … General Laws c. 209C, § 10 (a)… gives direction to the judge’s consideration of a child’s ‘best interests’ by ‘evincing a general intent on the part of the Legislature to maintain the bonds between the child and her caregiver.’”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: Such statements are harmful to the emotional and psychological well-being of the children and directly violate the existing order and the principle in Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The quoted concurrence in Smith v. McDonald deals with statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and relocation/removal of a child by a sole legal parent. It does not address parental speech, harmful statements, or a principle about emotional or psychological harm to children from such statements. The case is about the authority (or lack thereof) of a court to order a relocating custodial parent to return, not about restrictions on speech or conduct that might emotionally harm children, so it does not support the stated proposition.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: "If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child." (quoting Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003)).

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: One of the minor children, Noah, has begun experiencing consistent stomach aches on transition days between Plaintiff’s home and Defendant’s home, which Plaintiff believes may result from the stress caused by the ongoing conflict and disparagement, as contemplated in Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The proposition refers to a child’s physical symptoms (stomach aches) allegedly resulting from stress caused by parental conflict and disparagement, and suggests Mason v. Coleman contemplates this kind of situation. Mason, however, is a removal/relocation case focused on the best-interests standard in joint physical custody situations and the impact of relocation on schooling, parenting time, and alleged misconduct by a step-sibling. Although the opinion briefly notes a child feeling “emotionally harmed” by parental conflict, it does not address physical manifestations of stress, nor does it establish any legal rule about such symptoms as a factor, so it does not support the specific proposition cited.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “In addition to the developmental issues, the judge found that the mother’s children claimed one of them was inappropriately touched by the son of the mother’s new husband. The allegation caused considerable acrimony between the mother and father. This tension left the child, who subsequently recanted and then reasserted his claim of abuse, feeling ‘scared about his role in the family’ and ‘emotionally harmed’ by his parents’ ongoing conflict.”

Ardizoni, 40 Mass. App. Ct. at 736..proposition: Such conflicts are sufficient to constitute a material change in circumstances under Ardizoni, 40 Mass. App. Ct. at 736.
Ardizoni, 40 Mass. App. Ct. at 736..support_reasoning: The proposition claims that certain conflicts are sufficient to constitute a material change in circumstances under Ardizoni. In Ardizoni, the court did find a material and substantial change in circumstances, but that change was the mother’s rehabilitation from alcohol and drug dependence, not interpersonal conflicts (such as parental or sibling conflict). The opinion does not state or suggest that such conflicts themselves are sufficient to constitute a material change, so it does not support the claimed proposition.
Ardizoni, 40 Mass. App. Ct. at 736..relevant_excerpt: “In allowing the wife’s complaint for modification, the judge cited as a material and substantial change in circumstances, the wife’s ‘great success in overcoming her alcohol and drug dependence.’ … the wife’s progress in this regard, since the divorce decree granting temporary physical custody of the twins to the father, was supported by evidence in the record. Hence, the finding that a material and substantial change in circumstances had occurred was not clearly erroneous.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Plaintiff respectfully requests that this Honorable Court modify the existing custody order to award her sole legal custody of the minor children, as such a modification is necessary to protect their best interests and ensure their emotional stability, as set forth in G.L. c. 208, § 31 and Mass. Sup. Jud. Ct. Rule 1:28 regarding child-focused adjudications.

Mass. Sup. Jud. Ct. Rule 1:28.proposition: Plaintiff respectfully requests that this Honorable Court modify the existing custody order to award her sole legal custody of the minor children, as such a modification is necessary to protect their best interests and ensure their emotional stability, as set forth in G.L. c. 208, § 31 and Mass. Sup. Jud. Ct. Rule 1:28 regarding child-focused adjudications.

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Plaintiff further requests that this Court clarify the parenting time schedule to ensure that extracurricular activities are discussed and agreed upon by both parents before enrollment, consistent with Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: Hunter v. Rose concerns recognition of a California registered domestic partnership, legal parentage of children in a same-sex relationship, custody, and attorney’s fees. It does not address parenting time schedules, nor does it discuss any requirement that parents agree on extracurricular activities before enrollment. Using this case as authority for clarifying a parenting schedule regarding extracurricular activities misstates its holding and subject matter.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is]… what is ‘best for the child’… The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge… However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’” (Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 494-495).

Ginsburg v. Ginsburg, 429 Mass. 594 (199.proposition: Plaintiff specifically requests that the Court include provisions prohibiting disparaging remarks about either parent in the children’s presence, and that all communication between the parties regarding parenting matters be conducted through a parenting coordinator or a monitored platform, as authorized in Ginsburg v. Ginsburg, 429 Mass. 594 (1999).
Ginsburg v. Ginsburg, 429 Mass. 594 (199.support_reasoning: This opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case dealing with ineffective assistance of counsel and discovery sanctions in a murder prosecution. It does not involve family law, custody, parenting plans, non-disparagement orders, or parenting coordinators, nor does it discuss court authority to require monitored communication between parents. The citation is therefore inapposite to the stated proposition and does not provide authority for the requested parenting provisions.
Ginsburg v. Ginsburg, 429 Mass. 594 (199.relevant_excerpt: "A jury convicted the defendant of murder in the first degree, under a theory of deliberate premeditation, and of unlawful possession of a firearm... We conclude that the defendant is entitled to a new trial because defense counsel’s failure to comply with a pretrial discovery order led to an order that created a substantial likelihood of a miscarriage of justice."

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Plaintiff asks this Honorable Court to find that awarding her sole legal custody, combined with primary physical custody, better serves the children’s best interests in light of the harmful impacts of Defendant's conduct, as guided by Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The proposition asks the court to award sole legal custody plus primary physical custody to the plaintiff, and cites Yannas as guidance. Yannas does not endorse or discuss a preference for sole legal custody; it approves an award of joint legal custody with primary physical custody to the mother and focuses primarily on the removal/relocation and best‑interests analysis. While Yannas is authority on best‑interests and relocation standards, it does not support the specific proposition that sole legal custody combined with primary physical custody better serves the children’s interests in light of one parent’s harmful conduct.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The judge granted each parent ‘joint legal custody’ of the minor children and the wife ‘physical possession of the minor children.’ … The judge was warranted in concluding that physical custody in the wife was in the best interests of each child. There was extensive evidence concerning the children’s relations with their parents. The judge addressed the needs of the children and considered the physical care that each parent gave to each child.”
